unnormalised: I was completely shocked when I received my electricity bill last month. It was Rs. 3,500! I live in a small 2BHK in Bangalore with just my wife, and we’re pretty careful with our usage. Usually, it's around Rs. 2000-2500 max. I immediately checked the reading; the units consumed showed 450 kWh. I was like, what?!
normalised: I was completely shocked when I received my electricity bill last month. It was rupee three thousand five hundred! I live in a small two B-H-K in Bangalore with just my wife, and we’re pretty careful with our usage. Usually, it's around rupee two thousand to two thousand five hundred maximum. I immediately checked the reading; the units consumed showed four hundred and fifty kilowatt hour. I was like, what?!

unnormalised: So, I started investigating. Checked all the appliances – fridge, AC, washing machine. Turns out, my old AC was the culprit. It's a 5-year-old Voltas model, and apparently, those older star ratings aren't as efficient as the newer ones. It was running almost 10 hours a day because of the Bangalore heat. My water bill wasn't any better either. With the summer heat, we were probably using 15000 litres.
normalised: So, I started investigating. Checked all the appliances – fridge, A-C, washing machine. Turns out, my old A-C was the culprit. unnormalised: I ended up buying a new 5-star rated AC, and I'm also planning to install a rainwater harvesting system to reduce my water consumption. Hoping next month's bill is significantly lower. I've even installed one of those smart plugs that monitors the wattage. I'll update you all next month. Let's see if I can get that bill down by at least 1000 Rs!
